elements.title: Paul Blasingame (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Paul Blasingame was a member of the "inertial mafia", who advocated the use of inertial navigation systems, and he oversaw the development of the one used by the Apollo spacecraft (pictured)?

elements.title: Reflections (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that music from Mariah Carey, Sheena Easton, and Whitney Houston was the inspiration for the concert residency Reflections?

elements.title: Sandy Brown (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the ceramicist Sandy Brown wanted her sculpture Earth Goddess to be "female and making an impact"?

elements.title: Don't Wake Me Up (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Phil Elverum recorded Don't Wake Me Up nocturnally, while "drinking pots of black tea all night"?

elements.title: Ricardo D. Eliçabe (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Argentinian Ricardo D. Eliçabe qualified as a physician, co-founded a petroleum refinery, and wrote about forgeries of Bolivia's first stamps?

elements.title: Love Falls On Us (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the book Love Falls On Us, about the LGBTQ movement in Africa, was praised by author Uzodinma Iweala for "elevating the extraordinary ordinariness of L.G.B.T.Q. Africans"?

elements.title: Arthur Samuel Garretson (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Garretson, South Dakota, was named after businessman Arthur Samuel Garretson?

elements.title: Fast and Feel Love (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the plot of Fast and Feel Love involves a character competing to become the fastest cup-stacking competitor in the world?
